question.title: using jlanguage tool for basic spell checking
question.body:
I want to build a prompt with basic spell checking using jlanguage tool library. I have installed the packages (for english and greek as the languages I want) and the code compiles perfectly but when I run it, it shows me this error:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError

this is my source code:

import org.languagetool.JLanguageTool;
import org.languagetool.language.AmericanEnglish;
import org.languagetool.language.Greek;
import org.languagetool.rules.RuleMatch;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.List;

class GreekSpellChecker extends JLanguageTool {
    public GreekSpellChecker(){
        super(new Greek());
    }
}

class EngSpellchecker extends JLanguageTool{
    public EngSpellchecker(){
        super(new AmericanEnglish());
    }

    public void removeGrammarRules(){
        for(var rule : this.getAllRules()){
            if(!rule.isDictionaryBasedSpellingRule())
                this.disableRule(rule.getId());
        }
    }
}

class main{
    public static void main(String[] args)throws IOException {
        EngSpellchecker checker = new EngSpellchecker();
        checker.removeGrammarRules();

        List<RuleMatch> matches = checker.check("this is a textt with erors so manny erors thatt makee mee sick");
        for(RuleMatch match : matches){
            System.out.println("error in characters "+match.getFromPos()+"-"+match.getToPos()+": "+match.getMessage());
            System.out.println("Suggested replacement(s): "+match.getSuggestedReplacements());
        }

    }
}

I searched it in Google and it may be due to a missing dictionary or grammar.xml file.

  1. which files should I download to make my code runnable?
  2. where should I place those files?

It is the first time I use this tool in Java, so any help would be appreciated!

question_comments.body: I have never used this, but it sounds to me like you shouldn't use constructors directly. The example at dev.languagetool.org/java-api.html suggests you need to do something like Languages.getLanguageForShortCode("en-US"), not new AmericanEnglish(). For Greek, that would probably mean using Languages.getLanguageForShortCode("el") or Languages.getLanguageForShortCode("el-GR")
well this one did not fix anything the error is stil the same (it still includes the line "language already instantiated")

I don’t know anything about jlanguage, but Language was already instantiated suggests that you cannot call Greek() more than once in a program. Try adding private static final Greek GREEK = new Greek(); to your class, and then changing the constructor to super(GREEK);. Obviously, you’ll want to do the same with all other classes that extend or instantiate JLanguageTool. (In fact, I have to wonder if these static constants already exist in the library.)
